title: A Cognitive Revolution in Animal Research
excerpt: Animal ‘personalities’ are forcing scientists to rethink basic research.

title: How Octopus Arms Bypass the Brain
excerpt: A secret pattern links far-flung octopus limbs

title: It Takes a Lot of Elephant Brains to Solve This Mystery
excerpt: By counting the facial neurons in African savanna and Asian elephants, researchers made a discovery about the animals’ trunks.

title: Animal Magic: Why Intelligence Isn’t Just for Humans
excerpt: Meet the footballing bees, optimistic pigs and alien-like octopuses that are shaking up how we think about minds.

title: The mysterious inner lives of octopuses
excerpt: Octopuses are problem-solvers, mischief-makers and notorious escape artists. They also appear to have a rich inner life – so what is it like to be an octopus?

title: The human sensory experience is limited. Journey into the world that animals know
excerpt: In his new book, An Immense World, science writer Ed Yong explores the diversity of perception in the animal world — including echolocation, magnetic fields and ultraviolet vision.

title: Animal magic: why intelligence isn’t just for humans
excerpt: Meet the footballing bees, optimistic pigs and alien-like octopuses that are shaking up how we think about minds

title: How Animals Perceive the World
excerpt: Every creature lives within its own sensory bubble, but only humans have the capacity to appreciate the experiences of other species. What we’ve learned is astounding.

title: The Strange and Secret Ways That Animals Perceive the World
excerpt: Nonhuman creatures have senses that we’re just beginning to fathom. What would they tell us if we could only understand them?

title: Can Crows Make Mental Pictures of Tools? (Published 2018)
excerpt: New Caledonian crows were trained to seek rewards by tearing paper of a certain size, demonstrating what researchers say is quite advanced toolmaking.

title: How many senses do humans have?
excerpt: The obvious answer is five: vision, hearing, touch, smell, and taste. But the reality may not be so simple.
